title: 113_s364
content:
The Act is titled the "Rocky Mountain Front Heritage Act of 2013" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Rocky Mountain Front Heritage Act of 2013" defines key terms such as Conservation Management Area, Decommission, District, Map, and Nonmotorized recreation trail. The "Rocky Mountain Front Heritage Act of 2013" defines key terms such as Nonmotorized recreation trail, Secretary, and State. A nonmotorized recreation trail is designated for hiking, biking, or equestrian use. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Agriculture for their jurisdiction and the Secretary of the Interior for their jurisdiction. The State specifically refers to the State of Montana. The Rocky Mountain Front Conservation Management Area is established. The Rocky Mountain Front Conservation Management Area is established, consisting of approximately 195,073 acres of Federal land managed by the Forest Service and 13,087 acres managed by the Bureau of Land Management in the State. Any acquired land within the area will become part of the Conservation Management Area and be managed accordingly. The Conservation Management Area is established to conserve, protect, and enhance Federal land managed by the Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management in the State, in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. The Conservation Management Area is established to conserve, protect, and enhance Federal land managed by the Forest Service and Bureau of Land Management in the State, in accordance with relevant laws and regulations. The Secretary shall manage the area to conserve, protect, and enhance its resources in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The Conservation Management Area, managed by the Bureau of Land Management, allows uses that further conservation purposes. Motorized vehicles are restricted to existing roads and designated areas. No new or temporary roads can be built within the Conservation Management Area, except for rerouting or closing existing roads to protect natural resources. Temporary roads for motorized vehicles may be constructed as part of vegetation management. The Secretary may authorize the use of motorized vehicles for administrative purposes, including noxious weed eradication or grazing management, within a quarter-mile of specified roads in the Conservation Management Area. Additionally, decommissioning of temporary roads is required by the Secretary. The Secretary must decommission temporary roads within 3 years of completing vegetation management projects. Grazing is allowed in the Conservation Management Area under specific regulations and laws. The Secretary can conduct vegetation management projects within the Conservation Management Area, following reasonable regulations and guidelines from the House of Representatives report. The Secretary must determine appropriate actions in compliance with all laws and regulations, consistent with the purposes outlined in subsection (b). SEC. 4. DESIGNATION OF WILDERNESS ADDITIONS. Certain Federal land in the State is designated as wilderness additions to the National Wilderness Preservation System. This includes land in the Lewis and Clark National Forest, approximately 50,401 acres for the Bob Marshall Wilderness, and approximately 16,711 acres for the Scapegoat Wilderness. The designated wilderness additions in Public Law 92-395 are to be managed by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Livestock grazing and related facilities established before the enactment of the Act are permitted to continue following specific guidelines. The designated wilderness additions in Public Law 92-395 are to be managed by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act, allowing for measures to control fire, insects, and diseases. The designation does not create a protective perimeter or buffer zone, and nonwilderness activities can be seen or heard from within the area. The wilderness addition designated by this section allows for activities or uses within its boundaries, without affecting those outside the wilderness area. SEC. 5. MAPS AND LEGAL DESCRIPTIONS.

The Secretary will prepare maps and legal descriptions of the Conservation Management Area and wilderness additions designated by sections 3 and 4. These documents will have the same legal force as the Act itself and will be available for public inspection. The Secretary of Agriculture must develop a comprehensive strategy within a year to prevent, control, and eradicate noxious weeds in the district. The strategy should include recommendations to protect wildlife and natural resources, coordinate efforts with other agencies, identify existing and additional resources for weed control. The Secretary of Agriculture must develop a strategy to prevent, control, and eradicate noxious weeds in the district. This includes coordinating with county weed districts in Glacier, Pondera, Teton, and Lewis and Clark Counties for grants and agreements. Consultation with the Secretary of the Interior, State, tribal, and local entities, and the public is required. SEC. 7. The Secretary of Agriculture will conduct a study to enhance nonmotorized recreation trail opportunities within the district. SEC. 8. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife management on public land is not affected by this Act. SEC. 9. Overflights are addressed. SEC. 9. Overflights are under the jurisdiction of the Federal Aviation Administration. The Benchmark (3U7) airstrip use, maintenance, and repair are unaffected by this Act. SEC. 10. Appropriations are authorized as needed for Act implementation.
